text: <@UFCK510Q6> what Jon said. Haha. Yes, definitely fine to use a dev account. Actually, that's a good point. I think I'll add a note to the practicum description about that for folks in your position

anyone know of some special css property that I can use to adjust where the baseline is of a font - <https://spin.d.pr/LQjBSQ+>

This font is ridiculously off center, making it so the text always looks vertically off center even though it’s just off center in the font. the black box around the text is what you get when you highlight the text. as you can see it’s ridiculous.
wouldn't you need to decreate line-height for that?

yea but here’s the problem, line-height doesn’t solve the problem, because when it drops to a new line it visually is vertically spaced correctly, but because the font has that extra space below it, inside of any container you put this text in, it’s off vertical center
vertical-align: text-bottom maybe?
no effect
baseline-shift property?
doesn’t appear to do anything
:disappointed:
margin-bottom -5px?
Is it consistently off everywhere?
i doubt that it will look consistent with a negative margin

yes it’s consistently off everywhere this specific font is used, there are 2 fonts in use on the site. thankfully the user shouldn’t ever see the 2 side by side, one is used as a heading, the other is the base font
I can’t believe it’s an adobe font too

it’s Adobe Caslon Pro.

You’d think they’d have tested this kinda stuff
wow
negative bottom margin does actually work well, but it’s dangerous to use because the marketing peeps may use different fonts in different areas
just fyi: <https://www.cssportal.com/css-properties/baseline-shift.php>
doesn´t this should do the trick?
I could be doing something wrong using baseline-shift but none of the values seem to do anything
ok
Have you looked online for any other versions of the font? maybe someone else has compiled it into a more friendly webfont

I haven’t yet will consider it though. I’m at the point where I’m kinda throwing it to the designers and saying - “this is the problem with this font - you could edit the font to fix this and I could use that or we figure something else out”
in other news, I broke Google Chrome in quite the interesting way. <https://spin.d.pr/8J7EK0+>
<@U7SL518D6> Did you happen to find a good solution? enquiring minds want to know

hah, enquiring minds want to know.

for now - no. I tossed it back to the designers, as it seemed like margin-bottom set to a negative value was the best solution problem is I can’t handle every possible scenario they might use the font in. AJ found that the font basically just wasn’t designed well for web <http://www.typophile.com/comment/444450#comment-444450>

And there doesn’t appear to be a css based solution.

the only good solution is to use a different font file, whether that means an edited version of the font or an alternate font all-together
